title: 113_s883
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Refugee Resettlement Reform and Modernization Act of 2013". The Congress finds that the United States has increased efforts to resettle Iraqi refugees since 2007, highlighting the importance of resettlement for refugees worldwide without durable solutions. Many refugees are victims of torture, persecution, or forced to flee due to their support for American operations. The traumatic experiences of refugees necessitate protection and support upon arrival in the United States, with 58,238 refugees resettled in fiscal year 2012, including 12,163 from Iraq. Upon arrival in the United States, refugees are entitled to cash and medical assistance for up to 36 months, but actually receive only 8 months. Adequate support can help refugees become self-sufficient and contribute positively to their communities. Additional resources and better data could strengthen refugee services. Funding formulas used by the Office of Refugee Resettlement are retroactive, based on admission data from up to 3 prior years. Some refugees face mental health challenges due to trauma or torture, hindering their self-sufficiency and integration. Secondary migration is not adequately monitored, leading to resource shortages in states with high levels of migration. Refugee services are provided by various organizations and coordinated locally by State refugee programs to support high levels of secondary migration. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Assistant Secretary" refers to the Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for Refugee and Asylee Resettlement. The term "community based organization" means a nonprofit organization providing social, health, educational, and community services to refugees in the United States. The term "national resettlement agency" refers to voluntary agencies contracted by the Department of State to provide sponsorship and resettlement services to refugees entering the United States. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effectiveness of domestic refugee resettlement programs. This study will analyze how self-sufficiency is defined, the effectiveness of programs in promoting self-sufficiency and integration, and the budgetary resources needed to address refugee needs. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of domestic refugee resettlement programs, focusing on self-sufficiency, community-based organizations, and statutory changes to improve the Office of Refugee Resettlement. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. The Office of Refugee Resettlement will be elevated according to Section 5 of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish the Office of Refugee Resettlement within the Department of Health and Human Services, with the Assistant Secretary appointed by the President. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish the Office of Refugee Resettlement within the Department of Health and Human Services, with the Assistant Secretary appointed by the President. Amendments are made to various sections of the Act, replacing references to the Director with the Assistant Secretary. Any mention of the Director in other federal laws or documents related to the Department of Health and Human Services is also updated. Any document related to the Department of Health and Human Services or the Office of Refugee Resettlement mentioning the Director will now refer to the Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for Refugee and Asylee Resettlement. SEC. 6. REFUGEE ASSISTANCE. Amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding assistance for secondary migrants and reporting on secondary migration. The Assistant Secretary must ensure assistance is provided to eligible refugees who are secondary migrants. A report to Congress must be submitted annually, detailing states affected by secondary migration and its impact. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act include changes to social services funding and reporting requirements for secondary migration. The amendments aim to address the impact of secondary migration on states hosting secondary migrants and ensure assistance is provided to eligible populations. The Assistant Secretary must issue a proposed rule for a new formula for grants and contracts allocation within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The amendments will be effective at the start of the first fiscal year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. RESETTLEMENT DATA. The Assistant Secretary will expand the Office of Refugee Resettlement's data analysis, collection, and sharing activities to track national and State trends on refugees with urgent medical needs, including mental health conditions. This will involve coordinating with various organizations and utilizing refugee health screening data. The Assistant Secretary will partner with organizations to collect data on housing needs and refugee employment. Data will be gathered on refugees at risk of homelessness and their self-sufficiency for a 2-year period post-arrival in the US. Annual updates and reports to Congress will be provided. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE REGARDING REFUGEE PLACEMENT DECISIONS.

The Secretary of State will provide guidance on consultation with local stakeholders for refugee resettlement. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will collect and share best practices on stakeholder consultation.

SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act and its amendments will take effect 90 days after enactment.
